name: Can you help me build a decent lvl 13 bard?
author: Leroux

posts.author: Olivier Leroux
posts.content:
Hi there, excellent character builder elite!

New member here, was recommended this site over at NW Vault, since despite being a long time NWN player I don't really have much of a clue how you build a good character, especially regarding a class I'm not that familar with. I usually take the easy way out, playing clerics or sorcerers, but now I decided to play a bard, in a group of four, the other three characters being a cleric, a sorcerer with pixie and a ranger/harper. We're planning to play HotU together, everyone starting at level 13 and everyone can bring three powerful items of choice with them, the rest of the equipment should just be basic stuff.

So what Im looking to build is a lvl 13 bard for PvM, doesn't need to be a powerhorse, but a character who's able to survive in HotU as a team member while being useful to the others without being too much of a burden, and I would like to integrate these odd ideas (which might or might not work):

- Elf (purely cosmetic/RP choice)
- maybe using exotic weapons, possibly a whip? (just because I seldom use them otherwise and want to do something different)
- additionally or alternatively using bow
- possibly able to do some rogue stuff like disarming traps and opening locks, to support the pixie and speed things up (does it make sense to invest points in these non-class skills or not?)
- bards seem to have quite a bit of mind-affecting spells like "charm", "hold", "dominate", which I usually never use and don't know much about, I wonder if it's feasible to make this bard a charmer/manipulator (in addition to being a disarmer)
- items I have and consider using (three magic items are allowed): ring of STR+3, belt of STR+3, glove of Perform+6 (but maybe it would be wiser to invest in good armor?); weapons should be +3, but I could also use Greater Magic Weapon on non-magic stuff at the start, until I find better weapons within the module
- I was thinking about adding RDD levels, but I'm not sure if that's a good idea yet for a lvl 13 character or whether going pure bard would be preferable

Does that make any sense? Can you build a decent bard with these features or is this utter nonsense?

Also, arcane spell failure seems to be an issue with bards; how should I deal with it? By not wearing armor at all, by buffing in clothing, then switching to armor before the fight, by just going along with the risk and wasting spells in the process? What kind of clothing or armor do you recommend for this bard? And how important is the Concentration skill or combat casting feat for an efficient bard?

Thanks a lot for any help you can offer!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
When deciding how you want your character to be and what role/ part is should play, it may help to look at the other party members; what they are capable of and if they leave any gaps that need to be filled. 
I assume that the sorcerer is going to focus on casting attack spells, debuffing with Mord's etc. A bard will never be able to compete with that. Bard has some nice buffing and utility spells on its own, but there is a great chance that you don't even need that since you also have a cleric in the party with many strong buff spells.
Clerics are top notch melee characters, given their very strong buffing spells. They can also be great casters of attack spells and work great as "spell-swords".
The ranger/HS can have many roles, depending on how it is built; melee fighter, archer, trapper and scout are all possible. 
The Pixie familiar of the sorcerer can to some degree serve as a rogue, disarming traps and opening locks.
The most likely roles for your character in this party is either as a second melee character along with the cleric or as an archer depending on if the ranger focuses on archery or melee. In both cases your character can support the party with a bard song. If you go toe to toe with your foes (or at least within 30 feet), a curse song can often be very effective. 
How much you want to focus on rogue skills depends in part on what role the ranger has, and in part on how much the sorcerer player wants to use the familiar.
There are plenty of bard based builds for the roles I outline here.

posts.author: Aquarius 233
posts.content:
I stealthy come into this discussion to encourage you to not to give up on playing bards as front-line fighters.
Bards have been my stepping stone to spellswords, and can be quite tanks, thanks to some spells (for example improved invisibility/war cry/dirge/haste), songs (bard song/curse song) and access to a wide range of skills (for example, tumble for the extra AC, discipline, use magic device, spellcraft) ;)
For a level 28 HotU PC, as an example, you can build a:
  • Bard16/Fighter2/RDD10;
  • Bard23/fighter1/RDD4.
The bard level will provide you spells, tumble AC and a great bard/curse song (that lasts more time, for the second build); from RDD you will get ability bonuses and (if taken to lv 10) various immunities; few fighter levels will provide you extra feats and armor and weapon proficiencies.

EDIT: I know that these examples, as an elf, will take you an exp penalty, but I wanted just to give you some ideas on front-line bards. You may even want to play an elf bard 23/rdd 5: you will not take an exp penalty and you will benefit on a "very lasting" song and increases to abilities (and +1 to AC) from lv 5 RDD.

posts.author: Olivier Leroux
posts.content:
I vaguely remember about multi-classing that the order in which you choose classes may matter a great deal, since you might miss out on some things if you take a class at the wrong character level. Is that true? I think that's also part of why I was asking about a lvl 13 build initially, because with a lvl 40 build I have even less of a clue when to take what.

I could imagine playing a front-line bard, but I wonder if constantly having to pay attention to arcane spell failure and switching armor before fights isn't too bothersome in a multiplayer game without to pause ...

posts.author: Aquarius 233
posts.content:
I don't know to what you refer for "missing out some things", I'll only tell you that the level order can be critical: maybe there are great features you need to be anticipated to make the build more versatile or playable...

I am now playing a sorcerer spellsword and it is quite different than a bard one, as you have to cast many spells during combat (e.g. if your buffs are dispelled/wear off/circumstances need it: if a strong enemy is coming at you, you want to activate elemental shields to drain your opponents' HP because you know that he/she will beat your AC many times...or you want to use time stops/Isaac's missiles/etc...).

Bards are meant to use a little range of spells during combat (song excluded, as it is not a spell): haste, wounding whispers, dirge, war cry, expeditous retreat, keen edge. Other buffs can be casted outside combat.
Some spells, like darkness and displacement, are not subject to arcane spell failure.
Maybe other members will disagree, but I would advise you to avoid buffing a lot while fighting; for example, in many fights haste + bard song can turn the outcome of a fight. Wounding whispers can be used in tough boss fights; if you are swarmed by enemies better on investing on AC and avoiding uses of heals and potions, than damaging enemies this way (you have to be hit, and either you have barkskin/stoneskin/premonition on, or your  HP will decrease fast).
Besides, casting spells means high chance of attacks of opportunity, that can (best situation) damage you or (worst situation) damage you and interrupt spellcasting.

To deal with spell failure, you can take the "still spell" feat which make you cast a specific spell without any failure, at the costs of one slot higher than the spell's one. For example, a stilled haste would consume a 4th level slot; you can cast your 4th level spells as if they are level 5, thing to be considered as the only useful spell on that slot is greater dispelling.
You cannot still lv 6 spells, however energy buffer can be casted outside fighting....you will only lose dirge, but if you focus on AC you can fight without it.

EDIT: I am currently playing as a cleric spellsword in a server, and in my opinion it isn't too troublesome to buff during combat. Just organize your quickslots so the spells you plan to use are in places where clicking is faster (for me this is the centre of the bar). Don't be afraid to change the allocation if you aren't anymore comfortable with the current order.
